abstracts.cdata!:
The Project Completion Report for Sri
            Lanka is unusual in that it concerns one project that was
            not implemented (Mahaweli IV Project) and another that was
            only marginally implemented (Rural Development III Project).
            The Mahaweli IV Project was part of the Government's
            large multipurpose Mahaweli Ganga Development Program, which
            was aimed at solving the country's persistent
            employment problems and severe food and power shortages. In
            contrast, the Rural Development III Project was designed as
            a smaller, low cost, quick maturing program that would
            benefit large numbers of low income rural dwellers. In both
            cases, the implementation experience was cut short by the
            serious ethnic conflict which erupted in July 1983 between
            the Sinhalese and Tamil parts of the population. The
            conflict spread with increasing intensity from the northern
            part of the country to the east, eventually forcing the Bank
            to cancel the loan/credits for both projects. For this
            reason, the present report deviates from the guidelines
            usually followed in preparing project completion reports.
            There was little implementation and there were no apparent
            benefits, and it would serve no useful purpose to speculate
            how preparation, design, Bank or Borrower performance would
            have affected project results had the projects gone forward.
            The main lesson learned from this project was that the Bank
            acted prudently, with the Government's best interests
            in mind and taking into account the broader political ramifications.

727723.projn: LK-Rural Dev III -- P010186,LK-Mahaweli IV -- P010203

display_title.display_title:
Sri Lanka - Third Rural

repnme.cdata!: Sri Lanka - Third Rural Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Sri Lanka aims to raise the incomes,
            employment and living standards of the rural population of
            the Mannar and the Vavuniya districts through this Third
            Rural Development Project. It includes: (a) rehabilitation
            of irrigation tanks; (b) forestry and horticultural
            development; (c) provision of inputs and services for
            directly productive sectors; and (d) development of economic
            and social infrastructure. As a result, disparities in
            living standards within the districts and between the
            districts and the country as a whole will diminish.
